    Geometry Zen

    Geometry Zen

    Looking at the multiverse from a Geometric Algebra perspective


    Geometry Zen is an online tool providing Hands-on Learning of Geometric Algebra and Geometric Calculus to students and researchers in Physics, Engineering, and Computer Graphics using Python programming and WebGL 3D Visualization. It is the goal of this tool to make Geometric Algebra familiar to young science students and academia so that Geometric Algebra becomes the standard Unified Mathematical Language for Physics and Engineering in the 21st Century.


    ...for geometry, you know, is the gate of science,
    and the gate is so low and small
    that one can only enter it as a little child.

    William K. Clifford

    Features and Benefits

    Web Browser Platform

    Nothing to install. Just use a WebGL compliant browser such as Chrome or Firefox.

    Optimized for Mobile

    Designed to be easily used on mobile tablet devices.

    Modeling Workbench

    Juxtaposes an analytical programming editor with a 3D geometry view reinforcing the learning of the mathematical notation as well as the geometric interpretation.

    Python Language

    Mathematical binary operators are natural to use. Easy to learn. Widely used in academia.

    WebGL 3D rendering

    Fast GPU-based rendering provides smooth animation of simulations.

    Geometric Algebra(s)

    Support for 2D and 3D Euclidean (Now), Spacetime and Conformal algebras (Coming soon).

    Dimensional Analysis

    Automatic verification of the correctness of physical expressions (Coming soon).

    Units of Measure

    Permits algebraic manipulations, even if the units differ, with automatic conversion (Coming soon).

    Coordinate Systems

    Enter initial configuration in a coordinate system that reflects the symmetry of the system.

    Tutorials

    A comprehensive introduction to Geometry Zen and Geometric Algebra (Coming soon).

    Examples

    Allow you to explore the capabilities and potential of Geometry Zen.

    Works disconnected

    No need to be connected to the internet unless you want to share your work with others.

    OAuth authentication

    Secure authentication and authorization using GitHub. No extra passwords to memorize.

    GitHub repository

    Save and share your models in public repositories or use private repositories for assignments and problems. Search for public Geometry Zen models by other authors, improve on them, return the favor by offering back your changes.

    Issue Tracking

    Want something incorporated, fixed or improved? Discuss your issue with the Geometry Zen community!

    100% freedom

    Freedom to run, copy, distribute, study, improve and change the software.

    100% free

    That's right.

    Open Source Software

    What else would it be? Just head over to the Geometry Zen GitHub project.

    Geometric Algebra

    Geometric Algebra is the generalization of the concept of a number to describe geometric quantities and defines the rules for manipulating those numbers. In essence, Geometric Algebra is about learning how to correctly multiply and interpret Geometric Numbers.

    Many of the Physical Laws that describe the phenomena of nature are Geometric and Algebraic in Character. That is to say, the laws have a precise mathematical structure that is amenable to a geometric interpretation. Geometric Algebra unifies these two aspects in a single mathematical tool. By learning and using Geometric Algebra (and Geometric Calculus) the student gains a new perspective and a lasting foundation for understanding the universe and making new discoveries.

    Timeline

    300 BCE Euclid Geometry
    250 CE Diophantes Algebra
    1545 Cardano Imaginary numbers
    1637 Descartes Coordinates
    1798 Gauss Complex Algebra
    1840 Grassman Linear Algebra, Vector Space
    1843 Hamilton Quaternions
    1844 Grassman Extensive Algebra
    1854 Cayley Matrix Algebra
    1870 Gibbs and Heaviside Vector Calculus
    1878 Clifford Geometric Algebra
    1890 Ricci Tensors
    1899 Cartan Differential Forms
    1928 Dirac Spin Algebra
    1957 Riesz Clifford Numbers, Spinors
    1966 Hestenes Space Time Algebra, Geometric Calculus
